_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  Facility Policy:  The owners, management and employees of D & D Fertilizer are committed to the prevention of any release of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire deparment, and law enforcement personnel to mitigate any release to the population and the environment of our community.

2.  Facility Information:  The primary activity at this location is the storage of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received and stored while awaiting delivery to the farmers.  The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia stored at this facililty is approximately 130,100 pounds.  This amount includes our main storage tank.  On average anhydrous ammonia is only stored at this locationon, as needed,  during the peak planting seasons.  This is approximately four months during the year.  D & D Fertilizer currently lease this facility from the Cass County Cooperative Association of Weeping Water, NE.

3.  Worst-Case Release Scenario:  The worst-case  release scenario would be the release of the total contents of  our main storage tank.  The quantity released would be approximately 130,100 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  The distance to the endpoint would be approximately 4.4 miles

4.  Alternative-Case Release Scenario:  The alternative-case release scenario is a release from a transfer hose failure.  The distance to the endpoint is approximately 0.3 miles.

5.  Accidental  Release Prevention Program:  The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61, published by the American National Standards Institute, Inc., and the Standard of the U. S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration, 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia,"

6.  Five Year Accident History:  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property d

amage at the facility, nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

7.  Emergency Response Program:  Our facility has coordinated with the local responders and we do not plan to have our employees respond to a major release.

Planned Changes To Improve Safety.  Safety improvement is an on-going process at our facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess our prevention and safety programs.  There are no additional specific safety recommendations at this time.

For additional information contact:

     Mr. David Nielsen
     D & D Fertilizer
     15910 Hobscheidt Road
     Weeping Water, NE  68463
     (402) 267-3155
